note.body:
Benjamin Berg @bberg 
>  Is there any specific reason why the user might need the option even though it is a VM?

Other desktop environments on:

* Ubuntu 16.04 LTS such as Unity, GNOME FlashBack, MATE, KDE and Xfce 
* Ubuntu 18.04 LTS such as MATE, LXDE, Xfce.

ask user even on VM if he/she emulates press on ACPI Power Button.

What makes GNOME too unique to not implementing this? Why do you inventing you own rules how to use (virtual) computer?

Many users start to discover GNU/Linux on VM. VirtualBox has special option "Send the shutdown signal", you simply ignore it. Great method! Some users will ignore GNOME after such decisions, you should know it.

![close-vm](/uploads/dac2ae3c731b6d1140260be3e4dbcf90/close-vm.png)

So users may want to shutdown VM from GUI, or reboot it or even suspend it in standard way.

events.target_title: GtkFileChooser doesn't show all recent files
GtkFileChooser doesn't show all recent files

note.body:
Hi, I think I know what's the problem.
It's because of the limit in the number of recent files, the DEFAULT_RECENT_FILES_LIMIT constant in gtkfilechooserwidget.c.

I compared the contents of the ~/.local/recently-used.xbel with the list of recent files in the file chooser dialog and the recent files in nautilus, there were entries in the recently-used.xbel that didn't exist in the file system and gtk counted them when checking the limit defined by DEFAULT_RECENT_FILES_LIMIT but they are not displayed in the file chooser dialog.

I arrived to this situation by saving lots of files to the /tmp/ folder, opening them directly from the browser or by renaming them.

An easy way to reproduce the problem is to have more than DEFAULT_RECENT_FILES_LIMIT recent files and then renaming some of the ones that are shown in the file chooser dialog. Initially the file chooser dialog should show DEFAULT_RECENT_FILES_LIMIT recent files, after renaming N of them, the file chooser dialog will show DEFAULT_RECENT_FILES_LIMIT-N files.

It would be nice to be able to change this limit without recompiling or set it to a larger value by default.

events.target_title: GtkFileChooser doesn't show all recent files

note.body:
Well, maybe I wouldn't care about the limit if it didn't count non existing files nor the filtered out ones.

I had a look at the code and looks it's not so simple to implement the changes, specially excluding filtered out files from the count. Will try to fix it in the next days.

Thanks.

I tried 3.28.1 from flatpak, as well as 3.29.1-48-gc918052. They behave the same.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create new shared library template
2. Build
3. Open project_name.h

A workaround is to replace the include with `#include <glib-2.0/glib.h>`, which is not a feasible solution.

Funny thing is that when I add more classes to the project the includes work fine (after some time), but in project_name.h they still do not.

odd cairo.Context error

note.body:
The problem is that without signal handler override, ```context``` comes from pycairo (hence ```cairo.Context```, but with override, it comes from gi.repository.cairo (hence ```gi.repository.cairo.Context```). My guess would be because overriding signal handler causes parameter unboxing to be done in a different way (entirely within gi)?

Expanded test case:
```python
import gi
gi.require_version('Gtk', '3.0')
from gi.repository import Gtk

from gi.repository import cairo as gicairo

import cairo as pycairo


class Label(Gtk.Label):
    __gsignals__ = {'draw': 'override'}

    def do_draw(self, context):
        print("Override: type:", type(context))
        print("Override: is pycairo:", isinstance(context, pycairo.Context))
        print("Override: is gi:", isinstance(context, gicairo.Context))
        Gtk.Label.do_draw(self, context)

class Label2 (Gtk.Label):
    #__gsignals__ = {'draw': 'override'}

    def do_draw(self, context):
        print("No-override: type:", type(context))
        print("No-override: is pycairo:", isinstance(context, pycairo.Context))
        print("No-override: is gi:", isinstance(context, gicairo.Context))
        Gtk.Label.do_draw(self, context)


w = Gtk.Window()
w.connect('destroy', lambda *_: Gtk.main_quit())
vbox = Gtk.VBox()
vbox.pack_start(Label(), True, True, 0)
vbox.pack_start(Label2(), True, True, 0)
w.add(vbox)
w.show_all()
Gtk.main()
```

events.target_title: odd cairo.Context error

note.body:
Adding the following import seems to fix the recognition of cairo.Context as foreign structure, and unboxing as ```cairo.Context``` instead of ```gi.repository.cairo.Context```:

```python
import gi._gi_cairo
```

```
--- a/daemon/gdm-session-record.c
+++ b/daemon/gdm-session-record.c
@@ -257,7 +257,8 @@

         g_debug ("Adding or updating utmp record for logout");
         pututxline (&session_record);

events.target_title: With natural scrolling, horizontal sliders behave backwards
With natural scrolling, horizontal sliders behave backwards

note.body:
SCROLLED WINDOWS AND NATURAL SCROLLING
-----------------------------------------------------------

For scrolled windows, the input from the track-pad reverses...

  With natural scrolling DISABLED:
  - Sliding fingers down on a track-pad, slides the view down
  - Sliding fingers up on a track-pad, slides the view up

  And with natural scrolling ENABLED:
  - Sliding fingers down on a track-pad, slides the view up
  - Sliding fingers up on a track-pad, slides the view down

"Flipping" the behavior of a scrolled window based on whether or not natural scrolling is set, makes a lot of sense. That is how it should work.

VOLUME CONTROL AND NATURAL SCROLLING
-----------------------------------------------------------

However, "flipping" the behavior of a volume control, based on whether or not natural scrolling is set, *does not* make sense. Volume should always go up, when you slide up. Volume should always go down, when you slide down.

For volume control, the input from the track-pad should NOT reverse...

  With natural scrolling DISABLED:
  - Sliding fingers down on a track-pad, should cause volume to decrease
  - Sliding fingers up on a track-pad, should cause volume to increase

  With natural scrolling ENABLED:
  - Sliding fingers down on a track-pad, should STILL cause volume to decrease
  - Sliding fingers up on a track-pad, should STILL cause volume to increase

PROPOSED SOLUTION
-----------------------------------------------------------

In order to resolve this issue, I think we can apply the following rule:

  If
    org.gnome.desktop.peripherals.touchpad natural-scroll = true

  Then
    GtkVolumeButton widget should reverse the scroll event input

Essentially, the widget itself would undo the "flip" caused by setting natural-scrolling. Of course, if natural scrolling isn't set, the widget would behave as it normally does.

note.body:
That exactly is the issue: Lollypop has a play queue, but I can't **see** it.
Unlike with any other music player (unless Shuffle is on) I know, I can't predict what will play next unless I have a perfect memory of my past actions:

1. Some album-based players like Rhythmbox or Gnome Music don't really have this kind of advanced play queue. I.e. Rhythmbox will just play the album you started it with and if it is done, it will just stop playing. (Unless you switched to a new view before the end of that album, in which case it will switch to playing that after the other one ends.) But there is no way to manually add a song to your play queue.

2. Some players put every track in a play queue (e.g. Amarok, Clementine; all Android players I know of, e.g. Phonograph, Eleven, Shuttle, VLC, Play Music). And all of these players have some way to see and directly manipulate the play queue.

From your description, Lollypop should behave like (1.) and not have an advanced queue. But it actually works like (2.), except that you can't properly see the queue. I am actually fine with players that work either way. However, Lollypop has sufficiently many play modes and play views, that only (2.) can properly work.

Could you consider reopening this issue, please?

events.target_title: auto-suspend can't be disabled when GDM is active

note.body:
The previous suggestions didn't work, but I did find a solution.

```
$ sudo -u gdm dbus-launch gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.power sleep-inactive-ac-type 'nothing'
```

And another for batteried devices:

```
$ sudo -u gdm dbus-launch gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.power sleep-inactive-battery-type 'nothing'
```

I found this on the [Arch Linux's GDM wiki page](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/GDM#GDM_auto-suspend_.28GNOME_3.28.29).

note.body:
Not directly related to this bug (I may open another one on request), but @robert.ancell would you be willing to make it less inconvenient to select which scanner to use if you have more than one configured?

Imagine my use case: I have two multi function devices configured (home and work) and when I'm at home I want to use the scanner at home and when I'm at work  the one at work.
The situation now: I have to go into preferences and select the scanner everytime which is pretty inconvenient.
It would be nice if I could select the respective scanner on the start page / maybe in the start button.

events.target_title: Improve Startup experience / switching between scanners

note.body:
@aday @robert.ancell Since we talked about this in another bug report: I have a couple of non technical users and I think simple-scan is indeed simple and convenient to use for them. However, the switching between scanners is not easy enough at all, in fact unnecessary complicated. The starting page is empty anyway, listing all available scanners should be really straight forward, like:

```
Choose a device to scan:
Scanner A [preselected]  [Preferences-button]
Scanner B                [Preferences-button]
```

The user then sees a list of scanners and one scanner is preselected (e.g. the last one used or maybe the one currently available).
Right to the scanner could be a Preferences button so that it is obvious which scanner the settings belong to.

I think a dropdown under the scanner symbol might not be obvious enough for the average user, however it would still be better than the current situation.
The assumption that simple users only have one device for scanning configured does not hold. 

Would appreciate if you report back regarding your plan to address this issue.

Actually I was on X.org, but I should have also said I'm using the NVIDIA proprietary driver.
I got a similar problem on KDE plasma as well where v-sync breaks on the other monitor when I got two different monitors running at different refresh rates but I've been told X.org doesn't support multiple output v-sync
In GNOME everything except the mouse cursor and games even with this patrch just seems to be locked at 60fps, unless it's a wayland session using the nouveau driver.
The vsync breaks here in GNOME (nvidia proprietary driver + xorg) too when I open a game (even if I don't have vsync enabled on it and it is a fullscreen game) 

I don't know if it's something related to that but when I'm playing games, just sometimes on the 144Hz monitor even if the mouse is running at the correct framerate the game isn't, even if it reaches more than 144fps, and I workarounded this by reloading the session (while having the game opened) through ALT+F2 + R

note.body:
Hi,

Here are the questions that come to my mind when I see in the first mockups above:

- why clicking on the date should reveal notifications instead of the calendar?
- media controls look lost somewhere they do not belong to. Is it still relevant to keep them close to the notifications, while weather and clocks widgets are on a separate tab?
- it feels like calendar and notifications are not really connected stuff. Is there any reason to place them in the same popover, other than the fact that notifications pop out at the center of the screen?

As an extra goal, I would like to suggest to tighten consistency between the shell and the (new) lock screen, regarding both the notification placement and the visual treatment.

Therefore I think it would make sense:

- to move the audio player controls close to the volume bar
- to move the notifications to right side of the screen
- to make notifications pop out in the top right

Something like this, maybe?

events.target_title: Show only downloaded items
Problem resizing when rendering
Problem resizing when rendering

note.body:
Hi Thibault,

Thanks for fast reply. It's funny but right after my message I found the April blog post about Pitivi dropping pixel resizing. If the decision had been made earlier (I began my project February), I'd have resized all clips in Avidemux before importing to Pitivi. 

So I'm going to stick with my work around of resizing each clip on the timeline using the Transformation window, then setting a new 640x480 preset in the Render window. Though tedious it really does work. The rectangular pixels become square and all vertical image information is contained within the 640 frame width.

When viewed on my 24 inch (diag) monitor the image now looks really good considering it's 25 year old analog. Mind you I was using the best consumer camcorder available at that time - Sony Superbeta-1 with high band recording and stereo digital audio. Also used pro grade tape. Amazingly the tapes show very little image degredation after not having been played in 25 years! 

Running Pitivi version 0.99.0-130-g0f344b7 on Fedora 26.

John

events.target_title: Problem resizing when rendering

note.body:
Thanks for comments. As Pitivi is becoming such an excellent editor, I think it's important to eventually deal with the pixel conversion issue. I say that because there's so much legacy material out there that serious documentary makers will want to include in their work. Not to mention amateurs like myself who have years of personal material they want to revive and keep alive. At the same time I do understand you younger digital purists as I'm also working in 16:9 and am completely wowed by the image quality of my new Sony camera.

Yes, close the bug. Many thanks for your fast and courteous response - I know you guys must be very busy.

Thibault,

Thanks' for the very fast response! Am running Version 0.99.0-130-g0f344b7

GES 1.12.4.0
GTK+ 3.22

events.target_title: Pitivi Render dialog help needed

note.body:
Thibault, I just found this link that seems to answer my question about BVB Buffer. https://gameshow.forumbee.com/t/x1x2jr/why-a-custom-buffer-size-smaller-than-the-maximum-bitrate

Most important for me though is the question about the "Interlaced" check box. The mouse over says "for interlaced material". Bearing in mind that although I wish to deinterlace for computer viewing, some people would want to keep it interlaced for viewing on a TV screen, does checking the box mean:

1. The footage is interlaced so keep it that way, OR
2. The footage is interlaced and I want to deinterlace it?

It's also possible that because I don't see any real difference either way, the Avidemux clip splitter is deinterlacing the analog source material from the DVD VR (previously on Sony Betamax tape). Will look further into that point.

John

events.target_title: Pitivi Render dialog help needed

note.body:
Hi Thibault,

Don't know if you've had a moment to review my answers and screenshots to your points in message of August 31. As stated I have now cleared up my "VBV buffer capacity" option query and just found the below apparent explanation for the "Interlaced" query at this link under "imxipuvideosink":  

http://trac.gateworks.com/wiki/Yocto/gstreamer/video

_________________________________________

imxipuvideosink

This video sink is not nearly as versatile in output sizes. In many cases, it will refuse a format and bail out. However, one advantage it has over the imxg2dvideosink is that it includes a deinterlacer and can sink more video formats: RGB16, BGR, RGB, BGRx, BGRA, RGBx, RGBA, ABGR, UYVY, v308, NV12, YV12, I420, Y42B, Y444

This is only recommended if you require a deinterlacer to eliminate the effect of interlaced video effects or requires a certain video format only this video sink can provide.

To enable the deinterlacer set the deinterlace=true property.

The imxipuvideosink also supports vertical sync to eliminate screen tearing. To enable this set the use-vsync=true property.

_________________________________________

So, when you have time can you please confirm my conclusion that:

1. The default setting for VBV cache is way too low and should be adjusted to the maximum bitrate when using constant or variable bitrate.

2. The "Interlaced" check box should in fact be checked when rendering interlaced material that requires deinterlacing (i.e interlaced to progressive).

Adding clear info to the mouseover would be very helpful. 

Thanks, John

events.target_title: Pitivi Render dialog help needed

note.body:
Yes I agree appropriate presets would help. But for the time being a well worded mouseover explanation of "Interlaced" would have been nice. I may be wrong but "For interlaced material" is too vague a mouseover even I suspect, for people who understand about deinterlacing. I do concede however that an advanced user would know what VBV cache means.

Well anyway, I shall know in future to deinterlace DVD VR files in Avidemux BEFORE editing. Fortunately my interlaced artifacts are barely noticeable. But I'm a bit of a perfectionist. 

I will add that though I am indeed not an advanced user, my rendered footage would not have turned out nearly as well if I hadn't spent a lot of time trying out some of the advanced settings.

Thanks to you and the team for all your hard work on Pitivi

John.

events.target_title: Wrong content size for 'box' dav folders

note.body: You got it! Nautilus adds the (non-zero and accurate) "standard::size" of the folder I right-clicked on to the "Nautilus-size" of its sub-folders recursively. By "Nautilus-size" I mean "standard::size" of sub-folder + "sub-sub-folders Nautilus-size" recursively.

general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
I get that Nautilus hiding file extensions on executable .desktop files (CVE-2017-14604) is a bad thing. No argument there (and without Desktop icons ability to execute .desktop files is kind of moot anyway). I also get that the "Launch" option on the executable text files preference has to go. But why remove to option to have the "Ask" option for executable text files for which Nautilus doesn't hide the file extension?

So for games purchased at GOG.com, which come with a script GUI installer, users will now have to learn how to use the terminal to launch the GUI installer?

For simple scripts users may write, using say zenity for GUI, to automate some tasks on their computer they can no longer launch these from Nautilus? The terminal has to be used to launch simple automation scripts that likely were written in the first place to not have to use the terminal?

I don't follow the reasoning on this at all.

What's the difference between launching a script from Nautilus, having it ask what to do, and from Terminal? Is Terminal somehow more secure? No. So why inconvenience users and let them have the "Ask" option.

> Can you provide what scripts were you using that you launched like this?

Sure. To be clear, I set execute permission on such script files through Nautilus' context menu > Properties > Permissions. Launching scripts from Nautilus then presents me with the "Run in Terminal | Display | Cancel | Run" dialog. Using Nautilus 3.28.1.

I have a collection of Bash and Python scripts for automating repetitive tasks related to publishing documents, photos and more to websites. Few examples:
- tying together pandoc commands to transform source document into HTML, PDF and/or ePub format and a few simple pre- and post-processing steps using other tools
- automatic resizing of new photos, setting metadata on the files and creating or updating HTML gallery
- several scripts related to archiving and creating signatures for archives
- scripts to do full backups to external media of authored content

Scripts using standard Linux commands are mostly written in Bash using zenity to present me with a simple checkbox window to tick options for what actions I want it take this run. Like optionally uploading the processed files to the website. Simple scripts tying together commands with a little bit of logic and giving me options and feedback through simple GUI with zenity. Some scripts I'm doing in Python these days if processing of files is a more complex action.

Such scripts are useful only to me, for automating tasks in my workflow. I use Nautilus to navigate the files on which I'm working and to launch these scripts to processes the files I've worked on. It would be very welcome to continue to have the option to launch scripts from Nautilus for automating such tasks.

events.target_title: Use case for scripts in Nautulis
Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
## Trusting files

Trusting a file implying it will be marked as executable seemed logical at first: a convenience for users that don't know about filesystem permissions. But this obfuscates the task at hand and prevents the user from understanding basic filesystem concepts. If the problem is that a) users don't know about filesystem permissions or b) they don't know where to change them, I'd argue having a short tutorial in Nautilus at first run (and afterwards, until completed or dismissed) that also covers this (lightly) would be nicer.

But back up a bit because I'm missing the use case description for needing to trust files in the first place. I think how LibreOffice handles this is graceful. If the user clicks on a link in their web browser and chooses to open it with LibreOffice, LibreOffice will see the file comes from their web browser and will open the file read-only with this popunder:

![libreoffice-popunder](https://i.imgur.com/cfMpsMN.png)

If instead the user chose to download the file and afterwards opened it from their file manager, that being a deliberate act, LibreOffice doesn't open the file read-only.

### Previously taken deliberate acts shouldn't need additional trust

Looking at binaries and scripts these are the scenarios I can think of:

* The user downloaded a standalone, single file, program (binary or script), like an AppImage or sh installer, which thus has no execute permission set. It's a deliberate act of the user to mark the downloaded file as executable.
* The user downloaded an archive containing a program (binary or script), in an archive format that retains file permissions. Extracting the archive is a deliberate act of the user.
* The user created a binary by compiling something from source code. The compiler likely set the execute permission or the user would have to do that afterwards. Compiling in itself is a deliberate act.
* The user created a script themselves. It's a deliberate act of the user to mark the script as executable.

**All these deliberate acts imply the user's trust.** I thus don't follow the reasoning that for any of these scenarios additional trust would be needed before the program can be run. The user has already taken a deliberate act implying trust to make it possible to run their program; how is the cautioning the user another time safer?

**Note:** I'm not talking about .desktop files here, which could be executable in Nautilus without such a deliberate act of the user (and Nautilus hid from the user what .desktop files were).

I don't know that web browsers on Linux offer the choice to run a program when clicking on a link to it, like web browsers on Windows do. If that would be the case on Linux I think that is the scenario where, like LibreOffice, additional cautioning of the user is valid.

## Launching programs

Like others have said I think users coming from other operating systems expect to be able to launch programs from their file manager by double-clicking. Reasoning that the future is Flatpak or Snap, so call it legacy, marginalizes that users can compile programs from source, can write their own programs and can use programs from developers that don't distribute with Flatpak or Snap.

Putting the run option in the context menu doesn't enamor me. That's already getting cluttered and adding an entry here to run the program isn't any more discoverable for users that don't know where to set file permissions I think:

![context-menu](/uploads/e0d3aac288eb7ca9afab713387f09850/context-menu.png)

### How it (doesn't) work on Nautilus 3.28.2

That said, the reality with Nautilus 3.28.2 on my system is:

* I can't launch programs in system directories or that I compiled from source, because, as others have noted, Nautilus says it doesn't know how to handle "shared object" files;
* Launching a downloaded AppImage file before marking it as executable (okay! I actually forgot lol) throws an incomprehensible Disk Image Mounter error;
* Launching a (huge) script installer file, for example from GOG.com, with Nautilus set to default to displaying such files leads to it opening it pointlessly in Gedit. No fun trying to kill Gedit while it's hogging the system loading the huge text file.

Considering that programs in system directories would either be GUI and come with a desktop launcher or be CLI and need to be started from the terminal anyway, likely with command line arguments, I think we can safely ignore that group.

### A different approach

Whether the program is a binary or a script, I think Nautilus should handle them mostly the same way. Instead of having the run option in the context menu I'd suggest to attach it to double-click:

* For double-clicking a binary or script file detected as a program and having the execute permission I'd suggest to show a dialog with the button to run the program or cancel (the default for binaries), and for scripts also a button to display them (the default for scripts), and a checkbox option to attach the program to a terminal (unchecked by default).
* For double-clicking such a file not having the execute permission I'd suggest to use the same dialog but with wording changed to note that the file appears to be a program but doesn't have the execute permission and if the user trusts it and chooses to run it, Nautilus will set the execute permission on the file for them (unless that's not possible on its filesystem).

As I noted above, **I think asking the user to trust the file if it already has the execute permission is redundant unless it's opened directly from the web browser**. And I think in that case setting the execute permission to imply trust should be enough; no separate trust database is needed (but if Nautilus does go that route, I have follow-up questions about the trust database).

#### Thoughts on terminals

When choosing to run a program (binary or script) in Dolphin or Thunar, it runs without a terminal attached. I consider that a good default also for Nautilus, but with a prompt to the user.

Programs intended to be run from the terminal should be assumed to be smart enough to see they're not attached to a terminal, can't get user input, and abort.

I'd also consider which case we're trying to solve: the (I hope tiny minority) of users that download a program with no knowledge on whether to run it from the terminal or not, or the (I hope vast majority) of users that know that the program they are running from Nautilus has a GUI and for CLI programs would normally open a terminal themselves first?

#### Thoughts on program detection

The whole "shared object" thing meaning binary programs aren't runnable from Nautilus already was new for me. It looks though that the `file` command can tell the difference:

```
$ file /usr/bin/gedit /usr/lib/gedit/libgedit.so 
/usr/bin/gedit:             ELF 64-bit LSB pie executable x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0, BuildID[sha1]=0ca38a7c75e90f9140831e9f06a979b3bf3e71d1, stripped
/usr/lib/gedit/libgedit.so: ELF 64-bit LSB pie executable x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, BuildID[sha1]=b5a2d28202208ed48207f1857c5ab3c4d5082e0c, stripped
```

The `interpreter /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0` appears to hold the key to which of these is a program, at least in my testing for a bunch of other files.

For scripts I learned something new in that sh scripts don't need a hashbang line and, as long as they have the execute permission, will run like that. Neither Nautilus nor the `file` command has a clue it is something other than a plain text file.

events.target_title: Use case for scripts in Nautulis

note.body: I appreciate my opinion being valued. Took me a bit to formulate my thoughts on proposal #443. I already had respect for GNOME's design principles but being in the middle of this just adds to that; there are so many aspects to consider for just one user action!

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
## Deliberate acts

@antoniof I think I didn't get my point about "deliberate acts" across clear enough. I'm saying that Nautilus *only* needs to ask the user whether they trust the program iff it *doesn't* have the execute permission.

For programs that have the execute permission, a deliberate act of the user (setting the execute permission manually, extracting an archive or compiling the program from source) would already have preceded the user running the program. The fact that the program already has the execute permission thus means the user already did something that implies the user trusts the program.

For programs that didn't have the execute permission, the user saying "I trust it" and thus Nautilus setting the execute permission once fits that case with above.

Maintaining a separate trust database doesn't handle it differently or provide tangible additional safety, but makes it more complex to implement (what happens when I move a file already flagged as trusted, will the database be updated? what if I make a copy? what if I rename it? what if I delete it? what if the file is modified since it was marked as trusted? what if I do any of those actions with a program other than Nautilus?).

## Run dialog location

As for whether the run dialog is opened by double-clicking or from an option in the context menu:

* I was looking at my context menu and thinking it's already crowded.
* I'd prefer binaries and scripts to be handled the same way. What does a binary do on double-clicking it if, as I argued, for those that already have the execute permission Nautilus shouldn't need to ask for trust?
* For scripts you say that double-clicking to open it would be faster but I'd ask what would the average user want to do when double-clicking a script. Edit it or run it? For me personally (edge case, but still), I edit a script perhaps once for every 25 times that I run that script. For developers for sure it will be editing more than running and for average users it may just be running it never editing.

Ultimately launching a program should be obvious how to do and not need explanation from 3rd parties that offer scripts for downloading on how to make them executable and how then to run them. Perhaps the context menu will work for that but I'm saying also try sitting in the chair of the average user that doesn't write scripts, thus has no need for double-clicking opening the file for editing instead of what they likely expected to happen that it would run or give them a dialog with options.

events.target_title: Support OLC (open location codes)

note.body:
+1, OLC/plus code seems to be fairly compact, highly regular, and freely licensed (Apache2). It can be very easy to derive them from GPS coordinates, or to derive GPS coordinates from them. They also support arbitrary precision (like ISO 6709 decimal Lat/Long coordinates), enabling either fine positioning or coarse overviews.

Plus codes have a pretty wide potential user base with which to interact with as well, being supported natively within Google Maps both on the web as well as within mobile apps.

general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
I have to agree with @DeeDeeG on this one. This is security through obscurity, which is **not** effective long term.

>  @csoriano: You needed to turn on the executable bit anyway, which is unlikely you even know what is it if you don't know what a terminal is.

It *is* indeed possible to know about the executable bit without knowing about the terminal. Documentation could be made wherein users will be told to:

1. Right click an executable
2. Look for something labeled `Properties` or `Permissions` and click it
3. Look for an unchecked checkbox with the word `Execute` or `Executable` beside it
4. Check the box and press the Ok button
5. Double-click to launch executable.

That, in my honest opinion, seems to be a good balance between security and usability. If there are any doubts on whether an inexperienced user will have difficulty following these steps, maybe a survey should be made regarding this matter or get more community feedback before pressing on with this change.

P.S. ~~Could somebody please follow up with what happened to [this](https://github.com/GNOME/nautilus/commit/1630f53481f445ada0a455e9979236d31a8d3bb0) commit linked by @ivorget above? It seems to be a better solution that doesn't obfuscate user interaction as drastically whilst providing a sufficient layer of security.~~ Nevermind that; I found the answers on this [issue](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/437).

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
I'm in favor of this being implemented in lieu of outright omitting the ability to run executables completely from Nautilus. This adds a layer of security, while not making the user experience too clunky and obscure. 

As for executable text files (scripts), maybe some inspiration can be gleaned from what the KDE (please don't hurt me) people did and provide something similar to this: ![image](/uploads/4903ee74ff28e52a40273a1ebb8e7f17/image.png)

It (Dolphin file manager) prompts the user whether they would want to open the script in a text editor (left button), execute it directly (centre button), or to cancel their action (right button). Admittedly, I think that the Dolphin devs actually made it too simplistic in labeling the buttons. The Nautilus equivalents could be `Open as text`, `Run`, and `Cancel`. The trust checkbox remains, a checkbox stating `Run in terminal` is below that, and the counterpart to Dolphin's `Do not ask again` checkbox can be placed in the settings.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body: DistroWatch just started a [poll](https://distrowatch.com/weekly.php?issue=20180521#poll) this week asking users about their opinion towards running executables in a file manager. I would highly recommend that we monitor the results and take them into account regarding this matter, especially those who are directly involved in GNOME's development such as @csoriano et al.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
Hi all,

I understand this is for security and dealing with a CVE, and security teams felt this is the best way.

I respectfully disagree.

Basically, I think this too difficult for novice users to understand how to work around. Downloading things, finding them in file browser, unzipping archives, and double clicking the executable are the basic steps everyone learns in order to download and use software. That's pretty much exclusively how things are done on Windows; Windows is where most new Linux users come from. (macOS sort of lets you do the same thing, even though they locked things down a bit for "untrusted apps" in a way that I find also unfriendly to end users. But back to Windows which is a lot more users than macOS, statistically...)

Crucially, these things are doable almost entirely with the mouse. It's all visual and intuitive.

Setting up launchers, or using the terminal may as well be learning how to compile and package their own .deb (too alien and too technical, and too intimidating.)

Most people learn these steps (download, unzip, double click) as the basic minimum computer literacy in order to run apps. Learning about repos and software configuration apps is a skill most Windows users don't have. And many people are sure they can't figure out the terminal even before they try it. 

being able to download executables and run them from the file manager lets newcomers use Linux like they use Windows. These users need an easy way to do things safer, or they won't do it, IMO. They'll just get frustrated. Some will ust give up and use only preinstalled apps, others will assume "Linux is too hard," and give up on Linux. Remember, a lot of Linux newcomers rely on Ubuntu for being a safe and easy first step into Linux, so this potentially affects some of the most beginner Linux users out there.

Okay, essay over. Sorry for the long post.

In short, I think something that can be done quickly, intuitively and easily with the mouse is a must, or new Linux users will be frustrated or give up. Please consider the newbies on this. Thank you.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
@csoriano Okay, yeah I had seen that earlier in the thread but forgot to address that.

Even changing the executable permission can be done with the mouse. Right click, properties, allow running as executable.

I have had to do essentially the same thing on Windows, and also (similar to this), people from Windows are used to right clicking and "Running as administrator."

So I think setting executable permissions in and of itself is achievable for beginners and not a hard barrier to launching apps.

As long as launching app is only a few clicks and doable with the mouse, and not too hard to find out what to do, I am fine with the changes in this commit. But I believe this kind of change should be accompanied by some intuitive way to run apps with the mouse, from Nautilus. Whether it be native to Nautilus, an extention installed by default, etc. As long as a newbie can figure it out, there's no problem.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
The behavior of new users with low computer literacy may be embarrassing or disheartening, but these are real users, and most people I meet have lower computer skills, rather than higher. Looking down on these people, or ignoring them, either is a mistake.

There's a lot of these folks, so I'm just here to advocate for their needs. ~~If I can get more than a facepalm and a frowney-face in reply, I think we'd get further on this.~~ (edit: sorry for being a bit salty on this :/ I don't mean it personally against anyone here, I just care about this issue and hope this can be done in a way that is easier for users to understand.)

There must be a way to adequately warn users when there's a fishy executable, but still letting them run it "if they must," using just the mouse. You can put up roadblocks like macOS if you need to.

Or you could just require .desktop files to have the ".desktop" extension (and maybe trigger a warning for ".pdf.desktop", ".jpg.desktop" etc. so newbies don't get confused by a dual extension).

There are lots of ways to protect users without reducing usability.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body: Just to be clear, I am not a GNOME developer, I came here after reading the OMGUbuntu article, so I don't speak for the GNOME developers.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
I think that the Nautilus desktop folder functionality being removed does not do anything to make removing click-to-run executables make sense. It's pretty much not relevant.

And I agree this is an unusual approach to the security issue of free-standing executables. That users can still run these executables from the terminal means, IMO, there is no real mitigation of any security risk. It's just saying, "if you prefer the GUI, no free-standing executables for you. Learn the command-line."

If the GUI for warning users that they were being tricked into launching a .desktop file (per the CVE) was inadequate, it makes more sense to update it to better warn the user, than remove double-clicking apps to launch them. You could even disallow double-clicking all .desktop files. Or put up a hard-to-miss warning that even though it has a different extension, it's a .desktop file, that this is suspicious/might be malware, and should not be run unless you know what you're doing.

If the justification had been "we need to clean up legacy code and simplify the file manager" that would make a lot more sense to explain why this is happening. (I think the feedback against doing so would be the same, though.) And I still think this is not going to do much to increase security. People will just install another file manager or learn to use the terminal.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
My use case that would make me upset by this change, is I like to use Firefox Nightly. On Linux, this is distributed as a traditional tarball. (There is a PPA, but it doesn't update as quickly, and reporting/confirming bugs often requires the very latest nightly.) With this change, I would not be able to download/extract the tarball with the terminal (I don't have time to memorize tar commandline arguments), so I'd have to start in Nautilus, then jump to command line or another file manager to open the Firefox executable.

It would be pretty annoying to do this this way instead of being able to launch Firefox directly from Nautilus.

I could set up a launcher for Firefox Nightly, which I think would allow me to launch Nightly with just a mouse click from then on,  but I prefer to just find the executable in my file manager and open it that way.

Generally speaking, when I download an executable, including Appimage (e.g. Etcher bootable USB burner), I expect to be able to open that with my file browser.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
Okay, thanks much for the clarifications. 

> So, that does not block us from re-enabling support to launch binaries and scripts.

:+1:

In my opinion the use case for "launching" .desktop files is likely not very common, or at least it's probably much rarer than launching binaries and scripts. (I read some of the comments at OMGUbuntu, and I don't think anyone is mentioning wanting to launch .desktop files at all.)

(Edit to add: My understanding is that launching a .desktop file can register a binary and its app icon/descriptive text with the system, and app menus will know how to display/launch the binary. Something like that?

Edit 2: Apparently a .desktop file is both a launcher for the app AND/OR a collection of all the app's metadata as in my first edit; It can be either or both, depending on what you actually decide to use it for.)

I think a totally fine response to the CVE situation is just remove the ability to launch .desktop files from Nautilus; leaving binaries and scripts launchable would assuage every complaint I've seen so far. I would definitely support that 100%.

Yes, please do not open the terminal window for GUI apps! Some users will feel that GNOME is trying to "punish" them for using formats other than those which integrate with shell and GNOME will experience yet another backlash. Really, please don't do that. events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
Same, here. I would like to elaborate a bit:

In bioinformatics there are hundreds of small programs, each dedicated to one small, specific task. These programs sometimes have graphical interfaces and are distributed either as source code (if the source is completely free) or as binaries (when some fragments of the source are proprietary).

Many of bioinformaticians are not CS graduates and some are reluctant to use command line when not necessary; their every day workflow include working with such small programs and then combining the results and analysing these; They often write programs but it does not necessary mean that they use command line a lot (for example, when developing in RStudio, JupyterLab or Matlab you are writing programs which are executed directly in the IDE, which is very specific to the domain).

For these people, taking away the most natural way to run programs (as they often just switched from Windows) and forcing to have many terminal windows/tabs running (or learning how to send the apps to the background) will be quite a blow.

Also this is not reasonable to think that they could "package" these apps to flatpak/snap or anything else. People who develop these apps are scientists, not software developers. They are often under-represented  in the online discussion because they are not interested in the OS-level nor end-user app development. There are just so many of small topics for which there is an app or two, created a few years ago by someone who no longer works in this area / at the academic institution which has rights to the program so this is impossible to imagine that someone would be able to package these. There is a big difference in cost/benefit trade off when looking at packaging of Nautilus (developed by few, used by thousands) and topic-specific scientific tools (developed by one-two scientists, used by six-nine others).

Of course, we can assume that these people can create a `.desktop` files and place these in relevant location. But this is just so tedious and unpractical! Imagine that you are about to test 15 programs from 20 publications to see which one works the best for your new study; you will discard most of them as unusable, some will not meet your requirements, eventually 3 or 5 will stay and be used throughout the following two months.  Also, the "IT guy" (the boinformatician who is CS graduate) will help you and prepare 3 other tools for your analysis; probably two of these will be binary programs to use from your scripts but one might be a micro GUI app or a script which starts a web service (Django/Flask) for you (probably just a shortcut for you "not a developer").

In a sense, a broad community of scientists who are working with granular, domain-specific applications would feel negative consequences of kind-of faulty interpretation what the GNOME users needs. I would also argue that most of these scientists use GNOME as this is now default on Ubuntu, Debian and Fedora, which are the most popular distros for non tech savvy users.

I imagine that similar hurdles could affect biologists in general as well as some other academic areas, where establishing a competent IT support team is still beyond (this year's) budget.

Please, hear our voices. Similar point of view was expressed by Grzegorz Bokota here: 
https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/05/nautilus-remove-ability-launch-binaries-apps#comment-3902351388 and Beaver Fever here: https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/05/nautilus-remove-ability-launch-binaries-apps#comment-3902351388 

PS. Just to be clear: not all bioinformaticians are like described nor have daily workflow which does not include command-line use. Many have completed formal CS education and possibly would be able to write an OS on their own; however, as many are chemists, biologists or others by education.

note.body:
I can still easily reproduce it (using GLib 2.52.1).  I have a GLib + GTK2 build installed at C:\GTK.  Then I rename the folder to C:\GTKЖ (adding the Cyrillic letter zhe).  Running C:\GTKЖ\bin\gtk-demo.exe then always hangs on startup.

MinGW GDB has improved its UTF8 handling since the original report, so here is an actual backtrace:

```
(gdb) bt

events.target_title: [PATCH] Gettext initialization deadlock on Win32

note.body:
ATK, gdk-pixbuf, and GTK also need patches to avoid a NULL pointer dereference in bindtextdomain().  The Linux manual page for bindtextdomain() indicates that it should accept a NULL pointer okay, but the MinGW implementation doesn't seem to do so.

* https://github.com/audacious-media-player/audacious/blob/master/win32/patches/atkprivate.c.diff
* https://github.com/audacious-media-player/audacious/blob/master/win32/patches/gdk-pixbuf-util.c.diff
* https://github.com/audacious-media-player/audacious/blob/master/win32/patches/gtkmain.c.diff

note.body: This bug is so big that it makes the application more or less useless. Units should be preserved exactly as entered. Any ability to convert should be optional and required to be instigated by the user.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
I'm computer scientist working with biological data. No program from this area is distributed as snap/flatpak/repository. If we need to force non programmer to use command line interface we probably need to switch environment. Also forcing to manually create .desktop file is bad idea. There are no person who is installing software to other users.  

May add switch to advanced settings?

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body: @csoriano But in this case users need to use terminal or create .desktop files to launch the programs.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
> I'm not aware that iOS runs free-standing binaries? Nor Chromium OS? And Android doesn't by default?

And from this reason you need PC to develop software for iOS and Android. (I'm not sure how it looks on Chromium OS) and you have emulators of this system to fast test developed apps (in case of Chromium  OS i think Chrome Browser could be treated as similar environment).

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
If developer change environment they would write their application for other environments. 
It is high possibility that some developer writing custom software for some group mark it as not working on GNOME than will create packages from different distributions or creating instruction about `.desktop` files.

It is from my experience. Where I work in bioinformatics group and most of people creating programs are not good in meta knowledge about programing. 

If your idea is create desktop for geeks and simple user, but not nice use for person who would like to increase skills, then thees people change environment and they suggest it to their friends/coworkers.

Samples of big programs used in bio imaging 
http://icy.bioimageanalysis.org/
https://fiji.sc/
http://www.itksnap.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php

every of them are default launched by clicking in file manager. No snap, flatpak, deb, rpm etc.

events.target_title: Add "Launch using Dedicated Graphics Card" option when using proprietary Nvidia Graphics
[BZ#782967] Infinite spinning and high cpu usage while simultaneously show spinners in multiple maximized windows (loading several diffs)

note.body:
Cairo fix that hugely improves situation was merged in msys2 windows builds:
https://github.com/Alexpux/MINGW-packages/commit/f1eba2b29fa44643c3201e00867feaef331a9084

According to basic tests with near-maximized windows with a spinner only now more simultaneous windows can be opened on 1920*1080, without stopping event processing.

4k resolution has improvements too - now at least one-window-with-spinner repaints are fast enough to leave time for events processing.

Tests show that while cairo speed now nearly equivallent to native GDI speed, the rendering with gtk is still significantly slower than native GDI, but I didn't investigate  gdk/gtk parts yet (since the original cairo problem had much worse speed effect).

events.target_title: Missing visual feedback when launching some applications
Support TCRYPT devices

note.body:
Documentation and UI style guides recommend using the active voice over the passive voice whenever possible. Sentences in the active voice (and thus using "you" to address the user) are easier to read, easier to translate, less ambiguous and communicate more directly with the user.

When writing a user interface we are communicating with the user. Doing this is a similar way as we would do in a conversation is more natural, simple, and friendly.

Just to give a few references:

* GNOME Documentation Style Guide (search for "passive"): https://developer.gnome.org/gdp-style-guide/2.32/gdp-style-guide.html#locale-5

* Google Developer Documentation Style Guide: https://developers.google.com/style/voice

What made you think that we should not directly talk to the user?

events.target_title: Support TCRYPT devices

note.body:
I'm surprised by this phrasing of Allan which contradicts the GNOME Style Guide itself (and many others) but well... In terms of consistency it also makes sense to do like in the LUKS version of the same dialog:

* LUKS: `The passphrase is needed to access encrypted data on %s.`

So what about:

* VeraCrypt: `The unlocking options are needed to access encrypted data on %s.`

I'm putting "unlocking options" because putting only "options" sounds really weird: "The options are needed to access encrypted data on %s."

events.target_title: Support TCRYPT devices

note.body:
From a quantitative research that we did on users of Tails and VeraCrypt, some of these unlocking options are very popular. For example, hidden volumes: 58% of our users use only passwords while 65% of our users use hidden volumes at least "sometimes".

See https://tails.boum.org/blueprint/veracrypt/#survey.

So I'm a bit worried about having the title of this dialog refer to passphrases only and the current version worked well during the user testing that we did (that involved other unlocking options as well). But I don't have a strong opinion either since we'll have the second line anyway.

Your call!

events.target_title: Support TCRYPT in ShellMountPasswordDialog

note.body:
Hi Florian, I designed this interface with segfault and did 2 rounds of usability testing on it.

Our intention was to put the [Open Disks] button as close as possible to where it makes sense for users: side-by-side with the note explaining that it's currently imposible to unlock a VeraCrypt volume that requires keyfiles from this GNOME Shell notification.

See #note_276009 for the technical reason behind this limitation.

I understand that you are proposing to move this button at the bottom of the notification, along with the [Cancel] and [Unlock] buttons, right?

Doing so would indeed have the advantage of making the interface look cleaner but I think that it would have the following disadvantages:

* For the people using keyfiles: If we move the button at the bottom of the notification it wouldn't be side-by-side with the note on keyfiles, which is "right there" when people need it. They would have to look for it elsewhere (and maybe fail in doing so).
* For the people who are not using keyfiles: They would have to choose between [Open Disks] and [Unlock] without probably having read the note on keyfiles and might wonder what this refers to ("It is open my volume?"). While it's easier to get when the button is side-by-side with the note on keyfiles.
* During our usability testing, our testers were systematically confused when we referred to GNOME Disks as "Disks" only. When possible, we now refer to it as the "Disks utility". I think that moving the button at the bottom of the notification would require making its label longer than "Open Disks" to avoid confusion (while it's performing well right now).

Another option would be to remove all references to keyfiles in this notification and let the people who use keyfile figure out by themselves that they have to use GNOME Disks; or to only remove the button to open GNOME Disks.

For the record, in the quantitative survey that we did to understand what features of VeraCrypt people used the most, 42% of people who use both Tails and VeraCrypt use keyfiles at least sometimes:

https://tails.boum.org/blueprint/veracrypt/

But these are probably more advanced users.

events.target_title: Support TCRYPT in ShellMountPasswordDialog

note.body: Can you be more explict about what you dislike about this string so I can propose a better one?

events.target_title: Support TCRYPT in ShellMountPasswordDialog

note.body:
Ok, I understand better now!

Both "volume" and "keyfile" are the words used by the original VeraCrypt application and we believe it is part of the vocabulary known to the audience of this interface. As there is little point in using VeraCrypt in GNOME in isolation, we expect the people using this interface to have some knowledge of the original VeraCrypt interface as well:

* As it is currently impossible to create VeraCrypt volumes from GNOME, people will be opening volumes that have been created either by them or by others on another OS using the original VeraCrypt interface.
* As other disk encryption techniques, like LUKS, are easier to use and better integrated than VeraCrypt in Linux.

Our work is targetted at allowing easier cross-platform compatibility for disk encryption and so we think that we should stick to the original vocabulary of VeraCrypt.

events.target_title: Super+D wrongly leaves windows minimized if a new window appears
Super+D wrongly leaves windows minimized if a new window appears

note.body:
The motivation is that some apps create "launcher icons" on the desktop.  For example, Interactive Brokers creates a desktop icon to launch a script which starts their stock-trading tool (after downloading an update if appropriate).

Clicking that desktop icon is the only way to start that app.

Note that unlike with Ubuntu's old Unity, it is not possible to move that desktop icon into the launcher side-bar.

events.target_title: window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window
window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window
window focus change lags, some keystrokes go to the wrong (old) window

note.body:
I see.  It sounds like there is a conflict:  Fixing the keystrokes-to-wrong-window problem  by setting focus-change-on-pointer-rest = false breaks separate app menus for the reason Florian mentioned.

But, both issues will go away if the underlying problem reported here is fixed, namely by ensuring that keystrokes and mouse-moves are processed strictly in order.  I think that means queuing keystrokes typed after the mouse leaves the focused window until the WM can catch up and decide what to do with them.

Focus-change should still be delayed until the mouse stops moving, so if the mouse moves to a detached menu then the focus will still indicate the correct app window.  

(To recap: The WM would decide where to deliver the keystrokes; if the mouse stopped on a detached menu, then it could discard queued keystrokes which were not valid hotkeys for menu navigation;  if the mouse stopped in an unrelated app window, the queued keystrokes would just go to the newly-focused window.)

Can't you do it in a way which preserves compatibility?

events.target_title: (REGRESSION) ssconvert spreadsheet->csv merges sheets instead of converting only the "active" sheet

note.body:
Hmm.  That leaves out the key functionality I was using, i.e. 
"Get the current sheet without knowing what it's name is (and allow specifying the encoding, which stf_csv does not permit).

It would be a significant loss of user-friendliness to force the user to specify the sheet name.  AFAIK there is no way to determine what the "active" sheet name is, so this has to be known *a priori*, which in general is impossible.

How long has the change been in effect?   Given the long prior lifetime of ssconvert, IMO un-doing tje accidental incompatibility would be best, and would avoid removing the functionality I mentioned.

-Jim

events.target_title: SANE backend returning NO_DOCS during sane_read causes warning after last page
New unlock/login design

note.body: It is not clear from the design whether the shield can be disabled. Please allow this to be disabled, taking you directly to the login screen, or to the desktop if the login timeout has not occurred.  The shield makes little sense for non-touch devices, and there is currently no good way to disable the shield on GNOME, which is extremely annoying.

events.target_title: New unlock/login design

note.body:
>  Login happens on the "shield" as part of the new design, so disabling the shield isn't really possible if login is required.

The shield is only inseparable from the login screen if you design it to be so.  We're asking (begging!) to make it be separable.  To be specific, we would like the preference for a locked computer to go straight to the login prompt upon wake, and an unlocked but sleeping computer to go straight to the desktop on keyboard/mouse input.  Basically, the way login worked since the beginning of time until the shield.

>  I can see the case for this. Although, how is someone supposed to know if the timeout has been reached or not? There's a danger that they could start entering their password and it being forwarded to whatever app is focused in the session.

With all due respect, I think that's a circular argument.  You can't know anything from a blank screen, and it's yet another example of why I don't like the shield concept. Why encourage people to blindly enter their password in that state?  Who would even know to do that?  Nobody would even attempt to do such a thing unless they were already very ingrained to the concept of the shield.

I'm writing from my personal address, but at my "real" job I manage a commercial Linux-based product in use at 1000+ sites in North America.  We are a RHEL licensee, and we are in the midst of transitioning our client's servers from RHEL 6 to 7.  The number one user complaint about the transition to RHEL 7, by far?  The shield.  And we currently have no way to disable it for our users.  The main complaint is that it is an unintuitive extra step to login.  Yes, you can type the password straightaway, but there is no UI to indicate that this is so.  Heck, in the version of GNOME in RHEL7, there's not even any UI hint on how to remove the shield at all, or even what it is!

events.target_title: Define enum types for Unicode enums

note.body:
This change causes problems with the glib binding for dlang, and passably for other language bindings.

With this change and the latest gobject-introspection, the definitions for the enums defined in `glib/gunicode.h` will end up in both `GLib-2.0.gir` and `GObject-2.0.gir`.
Because of this when generating the binding based on the gir files the generator will generate code for both, leading to multiple definition errors.

Was this the intended behaviour for this change?

events.target_title: WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
Another fun problem. If we want to allow people to eval modules (which I think we should for the embedding story), we need a way to set the module's presumed location in the filesystem. This is for the case:

```
eval("import a from './where_am_i'")
```

events.target_title: WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
> I think we will need to keep two different code paths, then.
> I think `import './foo'` should probably look for both `foo.js` and `foo.mjs` (and even prefer `foo.mjs`?) but as far as I understand, we don't need to have different behaviour for the two.

For sure, we definitely need to keep legacy imports working. It was more a question of if we should allow importing legacy scripts through the module syntax. That way `.js` would be scripts and `.mjs` would be modules. This may be more headache than it's worth. On a related note, we should probably allow importing of modules through the legacy interface so that codebases can incrementally migrate from the bottom up.

> I would not be opposed to that but it seems to place a big burden on GJS

Yeah the more I think about it the more this seems like too much work. I've checked the API's in mozjs and I don't see one that lets me take a parsed file and ask if it uses module semantics (this would be a pretty efficient way to do it, but alas it does not seem to exist).

> Can you explain a bit more?

Sure, so the issue is that if someone is loading gjs as a lib, (I believe this is possible... but let me know if not). Then our API surface needs to allow them to eval a string as a module (instead of as a script). This has an important extra parameter which is the "location" of that module. This is important because module imports are relative to the file that contains. Without this location we can't resolve relative imports. Right now we allow fake filenames such as "<foo>". These are actually fine so long as they don't import something, but they have no canonical filepath. Further thought leads me to believe this can be fine so long as we require absolute filepaths for loading modules that have a location and we don't allow these top-level modules like "<foo>" to start with anything that looks like a filepath. That way, we only perform name canonicalization on relative filepaths. That leaves us with an API like:

- `gjs_load_module(GjsContext*, char* name_or_abs_path, char* module_body, ...)`
- `gjs_execute_module(GjsContect*, char* name, ...)`

I'm open to suggestions here.

> For the legacy importer we have `imports.searchPath`...

Module resolution is performed prior to any code execution. So any searchPaths will need to be declared before the module is instantiated. That is, modification within js will only affect legacy imports. That said, both the C API and the command line support providing searchPaths and I'm guessing that will be sufficient for most projects (and the old `imports` object will continue work for those who need it).

events.target_title: Epiphany crashes when dragging text using a second pointer device
Epiphany crashes when dragging text using a second pointer device

note.body:
Knowing nothing about any of the details, I'll post my 2¢ for posterity:

> Yet, while I agree that in `gdk_wayland_drag_context_manage_dnd()`, `_gdk_device_window_at_position (device, NULL, NULL, NULL, TRUE);` is returning `NULL`, I reckon that's normal and to be expected, because the device is precisely the core pointer and that pointer is outside of any known surface to the client, so indeed it can only return `NULL` here.

It's been a while since I did any C, but over here in JavaScript-land we've been starting to move all mouse events to (multi-)touch events. These modern events have a pointer ID which allows you to appropriately track multiple fingers touching and releasing in any order. The primary mouse is just the zero'th finger in this instance.

So rather than _"we've received a dnd event -> which window are we pointing at?"_, you'd have _"pointer ＃3 dragged and dropped -> which window is pointer ＃3 currently in?"_

I realize that an API change is probably the last thing you'd want right now, but if you want to survive in a multi-pointer world it's kind of inevitable. (If GTK already has pointer ID arguments, it just becomes a matter of passing them around consistently.)

> Well `gdk_wayland_drag_context_manage_dnd` is not prepared to handle `NULL` and will crash... what should it do?

Ignoring the dnd event altogether seems like acceptable fallback behaviour, wouldn't you agree?

events.target_title: Inserting an hyphen at line breaks looks wrong

note.body:
**Steps to reproduce:**

Open Gedit, scale the window to fit 37 characters, and enable text wrapping.
Paste the following text:

```
In this text file I've typed exactly zero hyphen characters. They are added by gedit or at least ostensibly so. It does so in a horribly inconsistent manner, though.
```

**Expected results:**

I expect the editor window, after typing zero hyphen characters, to contain zero hyphen characters.

Or for it, if I voluntarily enable hyphenation, at least to follow "prose hyphenation" rules, i.e. to only insert a hyphen in between syllables, that spaces at the end of a wrapped line are discarded, and that words in which it cannot safely insert a hyphen are moved to the next line as an atomic unit.

events.target_title: [proposal] add "Full screen" option to super+right mouse button window menu or titlebar context menu

note.body:
That's true for title-bar menu. What is worth noting here is, that super+right menu currently can't be disabled and works always regarding of title/header bar displayed and window contents so there's always "way out". Question arises if super+right can possibly be customizable (e.g. for minimize that I proposed here: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/issues/289). This indeed will make this option inside menu risky if user is not aware of shortcut key either alt+space or proposed super+f.

Regarding previous shortcut talk: for me saving space using system supported full-screen (for video/photo editing/3D/CAD/painting) is always welcome as this is very similar to watching move or gaming: games hide everything including top bar so whole screen is available. I can't imagine 3D with title bar and/or even top bar enabled like this blender window:
https://blogs.gnome.org/tbernard/files/2018/01/blender-titlebar-768x432.png
It's worth noting, that full-screen switch inside blender or games disables taskbar autohide (in windows), so it doesn't accidentally show when you are approaching top/bottom screen edge with mouse cursor.
MacOS has Control+Cmd+F:
https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/137361/shortcut-key-for-fullscreen-mode

Design question here for all CSD apps: is it possible to enter full-screen without hiding CSD header bar or making header bar autohide as text editor currently does?

events.target_title: [proposal] add ability to mimimize window using super+middle/right click

note.body:
No, no. I mean ability to minimize that works on whole window not only title bar so you can hide window regardless of cursor position above this window. This speeds up dealing with lots of windows. It's similar to super+left_drag to move window, super+middle to resize or super+right to invoke window menu. With this proposed option it would be like this:
- super+left_drag to move window
- super+middle_drag to resize
- super+right click - selectable between window menu and minimize and maybe other options, something like "super + alternate action": menu, minimize, maximize etc

More complicated way is how it's done in KDE and AltDrag:
![windows_altdrag_settings](/uploads/9c28eec19e10435cdc7d672554d03aca/windows_altdrag_settings.png)
![kde_window_behavior_settings](/uploads/5388e7ebc283dfbfd64074635b6403a7/kde_window_behavior_settings.png)

events.target_title: [proposal] add "Full screen" option to super+right mouse button window menu or titlebar context menu

note.body:
Regarding autohide: this is example how it's done on mac:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EbkbaQDFQ9U&feature=youtu.be
Gedit is perfect example how it's done nicely and efficiently without top-bar menu.
Thank you for conversation. Glad could share my thoughts here, maybe it will be useful somehow. I've got to rethink if there are other possibilities to enhance full-screen besides shortcut proposed earlier.

events.target_title: Ability to search in Nautilus and sort the results by column

note.body: I think there's one more use case of this one: recent files sorting. I know it's been disabled, but there's use case where actually sorting recent files is needed: when you want to sort files by time (default, of course) and type or size, to e.g. filter out only images or only documents you have used recently. This is common thing I use when I do my projects: to quickly separate blender files from documents or images. I hope this helps.

events.target_title: Prelight effect on hovered items is unnecessary

Thanks for the reply.
Alright, and just for clarification: what does "entirely removed" mean?
Do you mean the prelight? If so, isn't the current hover effect based on prelight only (I don't see any other effect upon hover)? So effectively, removing prelight removes hover effect.
I can understand that by defining icons as content allows this decision making process, by creating a dichotomy between links and icons, but aren't folders navigational elements in a sense (so the dichotomy is not perfect)? I'd prefer to call them actionable elements as clicking on files and folders does something and hovering over them tells us that an action of some sort is possible.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
I've experienced the same issue for a while. Although I'm not as technically savvy as @rugk I'll try and explain my experience.
After booting and logging in for the first time, the system slows down quite a bit. Opening system monitor shows gnome-software to be one of the top memory consuming processes. After killing gnome-software, the system immediately becomes snappier and remains so until gnome-software is opened again. After opening gnome-software again the same happens and the system slows down. Again killing gnome-software makes system snapper. So obviously gnome-software is causing the issue here.
Apologies if this is a very general description.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
@rugk thanks for providing the valgrind command. I used it to produce the valgrind log.
I'm not very good at understanding this log, but if I understand correctly @aklapper  is looking for parts of this log that look like this:

```
==12240== 1,280 (512 direct, 768 indirect) bytes in 16 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 31,433 of 32,925
==12240==    at 0x4939FAF: g_type_create_instance (in /usr/lib64/libgobject-2.0.so.0.6000.2)

==12240==    by 0x187FFD7A: ??? (in /usr/lib64/libxmlb.so.1.0.0)

==12240==    by 0x1879FC46: gs_appstream_refine_app (in /usr/lib64/gs-plugins-13/libgs_plugin_appstream.so)
==12240==    by 0x1892BBA3: ??? (in /usr/lib64/gs-plugins-13/libgs_plugin_flatpak.so)
==12240==    by 0x18931825: gs_flatpak_refine_app (in /usr/lib64/gs-plugins-13/libgs_plugin_flatpak.so)
==12240==    by 0x18933DA2: ??? (in /usr/lib64/gs-plugins-13/libgs_plugin_flatpak.so)
==12240==    by 0x1893485B: gs_plugin_refine_app (in /usr/lib64/gs-plugins-13/libgs_plugin_flatpak.so)
==12240==    by 0x19545A: ??? (in /usr/bin/gnome-software)
==12240==    by 0x1958A0: ??? (in /usr/bin/gnome-software)
==12240==    by 0x195AE0: ??? (in /usr/bin/gnome-software)
==12240==    by 0x195FF4: ??? (in /usr/bin/gnome-software)
==12240==    by 0x196584: ??? (in /usr/bin/gnome-software)

```

The only language I know is R, which is what I've used to analyse this data. I took all the first lines of sections like these that say xxx bytes were lost and have gnome-software mentioned in them somewhere. I've then plotted these xxx bytes lost. Here's the code:

```
vgdump <- readLines("vgdump")
temp <- grep("lost", vgdump)
temp2 <- NULL
for (i in 1:(length(temp)-1)) {
  temp1 <- vgdump[temp[i]:(temp[i+1])]
  if (length(grep("gnome-software", temp1)) > 0) {
    temp2 <- rbind(temp2, c(temp[i], temp[i+1]))
  }
}
temp3 <- vgdump[temp2[,1]]
temp4 <- gsub("==.+== ", "", temp3)
temp4 <- gsub(" .+", "", temp4)
temp4 <- as.numeric(temp4)

png("valgrind_bytes_lost.png", width = 15, height = 5, units = "in", res = 300)
plot(temp4, ylab = "bytes lost", xlab = "", type = "l")
dev.off()
```



Unfortunately, I don't know how to use latest master either. Sorry about that![valgrind_bytes_lost](/uploads/85b54bc177e165e6ac26e60a7ababa56/valgrind_bytes_lost.png)
