events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
On terminals: would it make sense to run in a terminal by default, but have some way for the file itself to declare *I will show my own interface, don't open a terminal for me*? This lets the developer decide, rather than pushing the decision to the user.

It could be the other way round - explicitly mark executables that *do* need a terminal. But I think terminal-by-default is better, because:

- It's simpler to write little tools that run in a terminal than to write GUIs, so it's less of a burden to ask GUI authors to mark the program somehow.
- Running a GUI program with a terminal is ugly but usable; running a terminal program without a terminal is totally unhelpful.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
I don't think extracting an archive should imply that you trust the contents to run arbitrary code outside a sandbox. It could also be a shared file on which another user has set the executable bit.

So I'd agree with @antoniof's idea on this: if Nautilus 'sees' a user explicitly enable execution, it can take that as a signal that they trust it. But the executable bit being set by itself doesn't automatically mean it's trusted.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
The notes you quoted for Ubuntu only apply to files without the executable bit - by my reading, it doesn't forbid anything once the execute bit is set.

OOTH, the requirement that the error message "not give the option of launching it anyway" sounds Ubuntu couldn't show the proposed dialog for any file without the executable bit set.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
Downloading an archive from a website and extracting it are actions you'd do when accessing pure non-executable data. Like a collection of  cat pictures, or some tracks your friend has recorded for his band. So downloading and extracting can't be taken to mean you trust the contents as code to run on your computer.

The attack it's all trying to prevent is the classic `my_cat.jpg.exe` situation, where I get you to open something that is actually executable code. And what makes it hard is that even if you put up a run/cancel dialog box, many people will click 'Run' without a moment's thought, because any time you interrupt people with a dialog box, we zero in on whatever option looks like it will get it out of our way fastest.

That's why the Ubuntu guidelines Carlos linked to say you can't just give an error message with a 'run it anyway' button.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
Yeah, that's not going to be terribly informative, unless anyone is still in doubt that people want to be able to launch things from a file manager. But I can predict the answer of essentially any poll asking "should someone take away the ability to do X on your computer" ;-)

The interesting bits of this are about how to balance convenience with security - how to let people run what they want to, while putting some sort of fence around the `cat.jpg.exe` trap. We're probably confident, rightly or wrongly, in our ability to avoid that trap by ourselves, so it's easy to say "make it as convenient as possible", and if you did a poll on that, I imagine that's the answer you'd get. But if the goal is an interface that non-experts can use safely, figuring out some kind of protection matters.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
Thanks :-) . I thought it was worth explaining a bit more why a poll isn't very informative for this, before it ends up on reddit as evidence that Gnome developers hate democracy or something.

I'll try to go quiet now and let people focus on actually figuring out the design.

events.target_title: 'View source' everywhere
'View source' everywhere

note.body:
I understand where you're coming from, but I think that saying "average users shouldn't care about the source code" is a fundamental mistake for an open source project. Of course there are going to be a lot of users who never want to look at the code. But a significant minority *will* want to look at it, and the easier it is to do so, the more likely they are to investigate, to become contributors or to get ideas for their own projects.

This is me for a lot of projects: I'm interested to know how they work, I'm able to follow code and sometimes change it, and I might well make small contributions if it was easy enough to do so. But I also have 1001 things to do, and for most GUI projects it would take too much time to figure out the codebase, the build process, how to contribute. So I'm interested in how to make that leap from user to developer easier.

I'm struggling to articulate this well, but I think the larger point here (not my specific proposal) is an existential question for FOSS. Are we building a 'product' from volunteer effort which will simply compete with similar proprietary products? Or are we building something that invites people to take the back off and find out how it works, maybe even change things?

For me the 'take the back off' worldview is the whole point of FOSS. If you're telling me that GNOME is built on the 'product' worldview, I'm deeply disappointed.

events.target_title: 'View source' everywhere

note.body:
It's not feasible with current tooling - I was hoping to start a discussion about how to get to a point where it is feasible. It wouldn't have to be visible by default.

But it's clear that I'm failing to catch your interest in the whole concept, so I'll stop bugging you about it.

note.body:
There was a 2.5 years old bug in bugzilla where you said [VTE was incompatible with GtkScrolledWindow](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=760718) and therefore with overlay scrollbars, making people think it is a framework problem. As you've just repeated that statement, it looks like there is no plan to change that.

Please correct me if I'm wrong but from what I can see, overlay scrollbars are implemented in [GtkScrolledWindow](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkScrolledWindow.html#gtk-scrolled-window-set-overlay-scrolling) but not in [GtkScrollbar](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkScrollbar.html), which would require the application developer to implement overlay scrollbars on their own. Where is the rationale in that?

Anyways, thanks for the clarification.

events.target_title: luajit dependency handling in meson.build is questionable

note.body:

events.target_title: Evince PDF Viewer cannot jump to previous history item correctly
Provide Horizontal Scroll Lock (for touchpad users)
Feature request - PDF annotation and highlighting buttons to main toolbar
Feature request - PDF annotation and highlighting buttons to main toolbar

note.body:
Not to start a debate but:
1. Lots of linux users are in academia and while reading research papers annotation is a must.
2. These buttons can be hidden when opening non-PDF files. They shouldnt be there anyway.
3. This I agree, but - firstly currently Evince doesn't support tile left/right with Super+L/R; secondly the document title can be hidden if detected the headerbar is smaller than a certain size. It wont help to display the initial three letters and a "..." anyway.

By the way, the new Gnome design language is indeed elegant and.... weird. I don't understand why they want to have everything in a single header/toolbar and with no way to re-arrange or add/remove buttons.

events.target_title: Feature request - PDF annotation and highlighting buttons to main toolbar

note.body:
Well my point is that there should be a way to re-arrange/remove/add the buttons, in headerbar or toolbar. If I'm using a widescreen 4K display, I probably would like to have all my buttons, which would be quite different from someone using a 12'' laptop.

I don't necessarily agree with you that removing buttons will confuse users. For example, with MS Office or Visual Studio (you can, obviously, argue whether those are good design patterns or not), the toolbar or tabs will appear/disappear depending on the files you're looking at.

events.target_title: Feature request - PDF annotation and highlighting buttons to main toolbar

note.body:
I missed the link and even if I did I probably won't read into some design philosophy articles either - not really something I'm good at or interested in.

Indeed it's a simple fix so maybe I'll just do that myself some time. Anyway, thanks for your time and all the hard work you've done for the project.

Can't connect to last.fm

note.body:
First, thanks for Lollypop. There are a few quirks and weird things, but it's otherwise a pleasant experience :-) 

Regarding this issue: it does not work for me either.

I set up last.fm on Gnome Online Accounts.

ESource is not writable right after being created

note.body:
Hi Milan, thanks for your quick reply! Here's a minimal example which seems to reproduce the steps from my tests:

[main.c](/uploads/3a00f8a88411fa08399d76961c30a4ab/main.c): on top of the file there's a comment with the exact command line I used to build it

[run-eds-test.sh](/uploads/ee343978b0a89a0045a72e5aa7ef6e40/run-eds-test.sh): the script I used to run the test

When run, the test prints:
```
test           : ** (process:19578): DEBUG: started
test           : ** (process:19578): DEBUG: Created source is writable: 0
test           : ** (process:19578): DEBUG: Main loop finished
```

events.target_title: ESource is not writable right after being created

note.body:
Thanks Milan, that's indeed the problem! After inspecting our full code a bit deeper, and trying it on two different machines (in one machine, the tests always succeed), I've got a better understanding of the situation: our implementation (which dates back to a version of EDS from 2014) expects the `"source-added"` signal to be emitted *before* the `e_source_registry_create_sources()` method returns.

I don't know if this is a reasonable expectation, but indeed our code fails when it doesn't happen. In any case I'll fix this by making our code capable of handling these events in whatever order.

events.target_title: Allow keeping screen on when locking screen.

note.body:
I guess I could have filed two different bugs.

1. Avoid turning off an HDMI device which has audio active.
2. Add option to keep the screen on.

I think 1 is super tricky because you need to decide what "active" means. Does it mean has a sound channel available (in case the user starts playing something) or does it mean that there is currently sound playing.

I think 2 is simple, easy to understand and provides a reasonable solution to the problem.

Presentation mode does make sense but I usually think of that applying when the screen is unlocked, which is undesirable in this use case. Although I guess having the ability to enable presentation mode while locked would be a good solution.

I think a lot of people want their monitors to turn off when they lock
their computer (myself included most of the time). However this bug is
about providing the choice to the user for either behaviour.

events.target_title: New color palette to match the new GNOME icons

note.body:
I've been playing around with the colours from the new palette a bit, trying to pick shades that give decent contrast against both dark and light backgrounds, and with various terminal applications (midnight commander, vim's default colour scheme, gentoo portage output, linux kernel menuconfig, etc). The goal was to be better than - or at least match - the contrast of the Tango palette in the applications I've tried. Here's what I came up with, formatted as a dconf array:

```
['rgb(45,45,45)', 'rgb(192,28,40)', 'rgb(38,162,105)', 'rgb(181,131,90)', 'rgb(26,95,180)', 'rgb(129,61,156)', 'rgb(11,186,244)', 'rgb(192,191,188)', 'rgb(94,92,100)', 'rgb(237,51,59)', 'rgb(87,227,137)', 'rgb(246,211,45)', 'rgb(53,132,228)', 'rgb(192,97,203)', 'rgb(79,210,253)', 'rgb(255,255,255)']
```

In terms of the palette entries:

| # | Dark | # | Bright |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| 0 | NewAdwaita Dark BG | 8 | Dark 2 |
| 1 | Red 4 | 9 | Red 2 |
| 2 | Green 5 | 10 | Green 2 |
| 3 | Brown 2 | 11 | Yellow 3 |
| 4 | Blue 5 | 12 | Blue 3 |
| 5 | Purple 4 | 13 | Purple 2 |
| 6 | Cyan 3 | 14 | Cyan 2 |
| 7 | Light 4 | 15 | NewAdwaita Light BG |

Reasoning behind some of the particular choices:
* Colours 0 and 15 aren't taken from the palette, instead I set them to match the terminal BG colours you get when using system theme colours from the NewAdwaita theme in the Dark and Light variants. I'm not sure about this choice, since the NewAdwaita window colours don't match the hue of the palette greyscale. If you want to stick to palette colours, Dark 4 and Light 2 work well.
* Colours 1 and 14 are chosen from the palette to get decent contrast against 0 and 15.
* There's fairly low contrast between the dark and light shades of some of the colours. I think this is OK since applications rarely do text and bg in different brightnesses of the the same colour.
* I picked a brown for colour 3 as an homage to the classic CGA/VGA palette (also it's nicely readable on both light and dark BG). I think this helps give the colour theme some personality.
* I picked a darker blue tone and lighter cyan tone to improve the appearance of blue-background apps like midnight commander, that often use cyan text over blue. This also helps vim's default "DiffDelete" highlight, which uses light blue over dark cyan in light background mode.

events.target_title: New color palette to match the new GNOME icons

note.body:
> I'd rather have a consistent set of 16 colors than match the system theme. Let alone not everyone uses NewAdwaita, e.g. Ubuntu goes with Yaru.

Yeah, that sounds like a good idea. I think we should use Dark 4 and Light 2 then, this is consistent with how Tango used an off-black and off-white in those colour slots.

> we'd also add corresponding text+background color schemes too

When I was trying this out, Light 3 FG & Dark 4 BG looked rather good together as a dark theme; the contrast isn't glaring and the warm text over cool purplish background looks good.

For a light theme, Light 2 as a background is too close to bright green and yellow, so you'd want to use white (aka Light 1) instead. Dark 3 is a good foreground colour, but it's hard to distinguish from black unless you have a hidpi screen or bold font.

But if you want something that fits in with the rest of the Gnome desktop, I think "Use colors from system theme" is the way to go here :smiley: 

> [bug 762247](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=762247)

I'm still not completely sold on this change... I'd actually prefer to choose a darker red and blue, but it would be hard to read on a dark background in many apps without bold as bright enabled.

> I personally don't really like seeing brown, e.g. in alsamixer, I consider it to be a "bug" for not being a darker yellow.

I wanted a darker yellow than the palette provided, and dark yellow in RGB requires reducing saturation and looks kind of muddy.  The orange in this palette was too different from the yellow, but the brown has a nice golden hue that goes well with it.

> I find it a bit unfortunate that blue and cyan have pretty similar hues, they're more distinct in Tango and other schemes

Yeah, this is the most noticeable change in this palette from Tango - the cyan gets a very strong blue tint (Green is kind of blueish as well). After using it a while, I'm ... okay with it, but I'd prefer a greener cyan. I find it interesting that [cyan has been dropped from the palette](https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/HIG-app-icons/commit/4e1dfe95748a6ee80cc9c0e6c40a891c0f4d534c) now.

For a more traditional cyan, use `#30B7CB` as colour 6, and `#38DAF3` as colour 14 (I generated those by using GIMP's addition operator in linear light mode to combine Blue 5 + Green 5 and Blue 4 + Green 4 respectively.)

> Also, do you happen to know if this color scheme has a name?

Not a clue! I didn't see any hints in the HIG docs. Maybe @jimmac has an idea? For now I'd just call it "GNOME", and hope nobody other than me remembers the [GNOME 32-color palette](https://developer.gnome.org/hig-book/unstable/design-color.html.en#Palette).

events.target_title: New color palette to match the new GNOME icons

note.body:
> I think the default fg/bg should be chosen from the palette colors, that is, have a total of 16 custom colors rather than 18. This is what Tango and Solarized does too, see especially the aforementioned 774619 for Tango.

Yeah, and this is why I don't use the Tango light colour scheme - the grey background is too dark and it makes some of the colours hard to read. If we really want this to do this, I'd use Light 3 `#DEDDDA` for colour 7 and Light 1 `#FFFFFF` for colour 15.

Then the dark scheme could be Light 3 `#DEDDDA` over Dark 4 `#241F31`, and the light scheme could be Dark 4 `#241F31` over Light 1 `#FFFFFF`.

events.target_title: New color palette to match the new GNOME icons

note.body:
So here's the main problem I'm having:

* In order to improve contrast of green and cyan over a light background, I want to make green, cyan, and blue all darker
* If I make blue darker, then it's hard to read over a dark backround
* The only reason this is a problem is that there's a bunch of applications (default terminal prompt on several distros, default coreutils ls colours) that use *bold* blue, expecting to get bright blue. But if "bold colors are bright" is turned off, then they unexpectedly get a dark blue instead.

push_data.commit_title: Add a new colour scheme based on the GNOME 3.32 icon palette

events.target_title: New color palette to match the new GNOME icons

note.body:
Alright, I’ve put together a new revision: kepstin/gnome-terminal@12025e88
The changes from the previous revision:

* Switched to a darker Blue, which allows using a darker Green as well
* Use the Cyan from the palette again

> Note that this is not a strict requirement by me (or anyone else I'm aware of), just a preference. But IMO all the colors, even if it's 18 different ones, should come from the given palette.

I wanted to try a darker blue than is available on the palette, so I made up a “Blue 6” for this revision by blending Blue 5 with the Dark 4 to make a new shade that matches the others. I think it provides better results overall – terminal apps already mostly avoid dark blue text over unset/dark background, since it’s unreadable e.g. on the Linux console.

(Of course, the way many apps avoid dark blue on dark background is by using **bold** blue instead, so… I highly recommend enabling “Show bold text in bright colors” if you use the dark colour scheme.)

With the darker blue, the palette cyan is clearly distinct from blue and looks alright, so I've put it back (reverting my blue+green blend).

I’ve put together a gallery of various applications in these theme as of the revision linked: https://www.kepstin.ca/dump/gnome-terminal-20190310/
Note that the dircolors and prompt used there are Gentoo’s defaults, but the dircolors match what e.g. Ubuntu has, and what Fedora uses on 16-color terminals (gnome-terminal gets the 256color dircolors on Fedora, which ignores the palette completely).

I’m pretty happy with the scheme/palette at this point in all the applications that I use, but I’d appreciate anyone pointing out specific applications or colour combinations that are problematic. Especially with the dark scheme – I find light text on dark bg uncomfortable to use long term so I haven’t tested it as much.

events.target_title: New tab does not get activated
New tab does not get activated

note.body:
You're right. Just installed the master version and saw that the GIT client was actually calling "meld -n **--diff** \<file1\> \<file2\>". "meld -n \<file1\> \<file2\>" however actually works fine and activates the new tab. 

I recently switched from Ubuntu 14.04 to 18.04 (fresh installation on a new PC) and copied the settings of the GIT client that was using meld on 14.04 already. The GIT client was always calling "meld -n --diff \<file1\> \<file2\>" and this worked fine (with activating the tab) on 14.04 but does not on 18.04. Don't know if this is intended. meld was always installed from the standard Ubuntu repositories.

Anyway, "--diff" removed, everything is fine. Thanks a lot!

May the issue is related to this section in the xml file
```
      <gnm:Filters>

```
where 65537 = 2^16 + 1

* Behaviour is the same in all of a small random sample of commits back to early 2017, so presumably it's not a devhelp regression specifically
* Docbooks for Python and Vala render correctly, so maybe docbook parser related?
* GTK Inspector flashes the DhWebView properly when the docbook renders correctly or when running with GDK_BACKEND=x11, but otherwise (with a C-language docbook and GDK_BACKEND=wayland) it stays blank. Maybe something is buggily drawing directly to the wl_surface or EGLSurface instead of using the GDK drawing APIs?

Things get more interesting playing with the WebKit inspector:
* Inspector renders fine (including GTK-inspector-blinking!) unless one switches to the experimental 'Layers' tab, in which case it becomes invisible again
* On docbooks for other langs, the rendering goes blank when moving the mouse over the inspector area

events.target_title: Value marshaller assumes types encoded via GI_INFO_TYPE_OBJECT derive from GObject or GParamSpec
Value marshaller assumes types encoded via GI_INFO_TYPE_OBJECT derive from GObject or GParamSpec

note.body: Digging through the code and some other relevant issues, it seems like properly supporting arbitrary fundamental classed types would be a significant undertaking. Would it be an acceptable stop-gap to expose some hooks into `_arg_cache_new_for_interface` ([pygi-cache.c:277](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pygobject/blob/3.32.1/gi/pygi-cache.c#L277)) to allow extensions to handle their own object<->wrapper marshaling?

events.target_title: Value marshaller assumes types encoded via GI_INFO_TYPE_OBJECT derive from GObject or GParamSpec

note.body:
I've been playing around with a quick-and-dirty fundamental type wrapper implementation (nothing like in #8, instead just bolting on a fairly minimal wrapper object and fixing up the various `GI_INFO_TYPE_OBJECT` bits; a place to start, or at the very least an example of what not to do in PyGI), but there's one specific problem I keep tripping over: how should missing ref/unref functions be handled? There's four possible scenarios:

 - Have both ref and unref
 - Have neither ref nor unref
 - Have only unref: abuse of annotations to specify a free function?
 - Have only ref: seems completely nonsensical, barring perhaps abuse as a hook for some tracing system?

The first is fairly straightforward, but the next two have me stumped. For instance, if a function parameter is annotated to take ownership of a value for which the corresponding type has no annotated ref function, what is meant to happen to the Python wrapper? Can it be safely deleted?

Similarly in the case of a missing unref function, is it preferable to log a critical message/raise an exception or to assume the GIR writer/generator knew what they were doing? If the latter, should the lack of an unref function change the semantics of ownership/transfer? How?

---

Another thing I might mention: the more I think about it, the more confused I am regarding the purpose of the get/set value annotations. AFAICT, a type needs to have a value table to be stored in a GValue, and a derived type with different GValue storage semantics than those of its parent would probably break things. I'm operating on the assumption that it's okay to ignore the functions specified in the typelib and just use `g_value_set_instance`/`g_value_peek_pointer` (a la GObject code unconditionally using `g_value_{set,get}_object`), but is this really correct?

events.target_title: Major UI process memory corruption

note.body:
There's a great tool called [rr](https://rr-project.org/) that's really very useful in these situations. My typical workflow is to record a trace of the crash, replay the trace until the crash, set a watchpoint on whatever clobbered memory caused the crash and reverse-replay until the watchpoint triggers. I've had mixed luck with browser-y things in the past since it disables things like hardware-accelerated rendering to remove sources of non-determinism from the trace replay, but if it's not directly related to anything like that then it should work fine.

I tried to give it a go myself, but I got bored fighting with flatpak ;)

events.target_title: gsd-rfkill can't cope with hotplugged rfkill devices
Rygel blacklists video files as they're being downloaded

note.body:
There is no way this could possibly be an expected behavior, you shouldn't even be attempting to index the file until you get the IN_CLOSE_WRITE notification from inotify and you should attempt to index it every time you get such a notification, even when it is already in the blacklist.

Note that this also happens when you copy a file from slow media (e.g. a USB stick) into a folder served by Rygel.

some more info/thoughts -- at this point should I close this bug and file 3 new ones for 1,2,4 and use the existing g-c-c one for 3?:

(1) If it only did this the first time, it'd be "ok", but combining it with (4) makes it rather irritating

events.target_title: Auto-generated tags for brushes
New instances to Brushes | Proposal

note.body:
The quote below is from Jehan responding to Americo's original post above. (My apologies, it's probably there, but I don't see in this new gitlab stuff an easy way to quote and attribute.)
> 1/ I don't think we should divide the brush assets. Once created, from the painter's point of view (even when painter and creator are the same), one doesn't care at all how they were built. Parametric, raster, who cares? Only on creation side, one cares. 

Maybe I misunderstand what you mean in the above comment. But from *this* painter's point of view, it makes a great big *huge* difference whether a brush is parametric or gih or gbr, simply because each brush type provides different painting possibilities. As per issue 1553 I made tags for all my brushes *specifically* so I can easily find "all brushes of a given type (vbr, gbr, or gih) at a specific size range".

In Krita it's very easy to see "all and only brushes of type X" and when using Krita, I use this capacity all the time. The type of brush absolutely plays into the kinds of mark one can make, alone or when combined with various dynamics. It would be *very* nice if GIMP also provided this information to users in a easy to use somehow autogenerated "show me only brushes of type X", preferably via tags so the user can ask for "brushes of type X that also have tags Y/Z/etc".

events.target_title: Excessive gamma correction for the  for text layers due to the "Default" blending mode

note.body:
Quoting Mitch:
>  This is a bit of a dilemma because 2.8 is wrong, and 2.10 doesn't look right when rendered black-on-white where you can't see any wrong colors.

>  Regardless, we must somehow solve the problem...
End quoting Mitch

Even for color text (say Red) on a color background (say Green), the text "looks funny" if you expect it to look like text looks in GIMP-2.8 or other image editor that mixes colors in perceptually uniform RGB. The Red looks lighter. And using Legacy blend you don't actually see the gamma artifacts (dark blend areas) until you zoom in (or if the text is relatively large).

This issue of "not dark enough" using default (linear) blend for text layers might be a matter of user education/expectations. FWIW (probably not much), I've been making text layers using GIMP-2.9/2.10 for several years now, though only occasionally and only for small amounts of text (labels for illustration), and I've never resorted to using legacy blending to make the text darker, probably because I never used GIMP-2.8 so didn't have any expectations about how the text "should" look. 

But thinking back, I do often duplicate a text layer to make the colors more uniformly filled in, or else I'll switch to Bold letters.

So if the text layer looks "too light around the edges" when the layer is blended using linear RGB (including blending black letters on a white background), a nice workaround is to duplicate the layer and the colors are more uniformly filled in across the width of the letter strokes, but without gamma artifacts - much nicer rendition than depending on "gamma artifacts" to darken the blended areas.

Maybe the real problem is that antialiasing for text is set up on the assumption that the colors are being blended using perceptually uniform RGB.

events.target_title: Color to alpha tool makes washed out colors

note.body:
I'd never heard of "color to alpha" but located it under the Colors menu and gave it a try: 

If the default layer composite space is used, and the layer blend is set to "Normal/Default", then the colors are indeed washed out.

If the layer blend is left at "Normal/Default" and the layer composite space is set to Perceptual, then putting the layer over white reproduces the original image.

Also if the layer blend mode is set to "Normal/Legacy", then the original image is reproduced.

events.target_title: Color to alpha tool makes washed out colors

note.body:
Checking the "gamma hack" in the "Advanced Color Options" that can be enabled through Preferences also reproduces the original image.

I'm guessing that default settings that produce the original colors would be better than leaving it to the user to figure out which magic combination of settings will produce the original colors.

Here are some questions - I've never used this operation in actual image editing, so I apologize in advance if the questions are totally irrelevant:

Is there a use case for the current "by default mix" of doing Color to alpha using Perceptual, but compositing using Linear?

Would it make sense to allow Color to alpha to also work in linear RGB at the user's choice, maybe through a checkbox in the UI? Checking in my hacked version of GIMP with the babl TRC transforms disabled and operating in a linear RGB color space, one does get the original colors back when using the old GEGL WorkShop "Color to Alpha +" operation. 

What changes if any would result when using Perceptual throughout vs using Linear throughout, in terms of further processing? 

Is there a color mixing advantage to doing all the operations (Color to alpha and also Compositing) using Linear RGB? In other words, are there gamma artifacts from using Perceptual RGB for Color to alpha and also for the Composite space, when additional processing is done on the "Color to alpha" layer?

note.body:
FWIW, I can't reproduce this behavior on Gentoo Linux using GIMP 2.10 from git updated this morning. On my machine the size on disk is consistently reported by Dolphin as slightly smaller than the size given in the jpeg export dialog - I think this is from differences in how a "kB" is calculated by each program. This was true across a range of image sizes.

I also tried exporting with/without embedded metadata/thumbnail - even with embedded metadata/thumbnail the size on disk is still not quite as big as the calculated size. But as the calculated file size didn't change when exporting or not exporting metadata/thumbnail, maybe an image opened from disk with huge amounts of metadata could cause a significant increase in the size of the exported image on disk, compared to the calcuated size?

I checked to see if somehow "Use quality settings from original image" might be affecting the size on disk, but still couldn't get the size on disk to be larger than the calculated size. Also I tried exporting a jpeg with the XCF file at 16i and at 32f, with same results. But I didn't try exporting a jpeg from an 8-bit XCF file.

Maybe there is some very explicit set of jpeg export settings combination that causes issues? Here are the settings I used for all the exported jpegs: Quality 97%, and under Advanced Options: Progressive, Subsampling 4:4:4, DCT method Floating-Point.

events.target_title: Support waiting for child process to exit in `gio open`

note.body:
Adapted from #652262 comment #15:

There is a related problem also caused by gio open exiting too early: if gio is run under a new pty, then it is the session group leader, and when it exits, its children are killed. There's a race condition: sometimes they can have had time to detach themselves (this can be made to happen by running gio open under ltrace); other times, gio open completes successfully, but the child is killed.

The fix is to have gio open call setsid() to put it in its own process group.

I came across the problem when running gio open from xdg-open (which is a shell script), and I was able to work around it by calling gio open as "setsid gio open". Of course, that doesn't help when gio open is invoked directly.

events.target_title: Support waiting for child process to exit in `gio open`

note.body:
Here's what I previously said about fixing this bug (adapted to be more self-contained):

There are conflicting requirements: some users/uses want to start the child asynchronously (e.g. nautilus, or users "launching" files from the command line); some want to wait until it terminates (e.g. terminal programs like Mutt that want to launch helpers synchronously).

It might be argued that users should use "&" and programs running gio open should fork, but it's too late: users and code already rely on the current behaviour.

Therefore, we should support both. For the asynchronous case, Ross Lagerwall's suggestion (bug #652262 comment #33) suggestion that "g_app_info_launch_default_for_uri should run the child in a clean state" works nicely.

For the synchronous case, add a -w flag, to make gio open wait for the process it runs to terminate. A simple implementation won't work for single instance applications (the executed binary will send a message to the running instance and then exit); support would have to be added to cover that case, such as already exists in Emacs as exploited by emacsclient.

The implementation approach is then threefold:

1. Run the child in a clean state.

2. Add a simple "-w" flag.

3. Add support for waiting on messages to single instance applications.

Some might consider 2 not worth doing without 3.

Finally, using nohup is not a good idea, for two reasons:

1. It creates an output file.

2. It makes child processes insensitive to NOHUP, rather than simply preventing NOHUP being propagated from gvfs-open to its children.

Further, running "eog foo.png &" and then closing the terminal will ALWAYS close eog. However, running "gio open foo.png" and then closing the terminal will close eog if it is done very quickly, but not if gio open has already exited.

In other words, there's a definite race condition here, which should be solved. Both parts of the solution above fix it: when used asynchronously, gio open will no longer cause the command it launches to be SIGHUP'd on exit (because it won't be in the same session); when used synchronously, gio open will always still be there to be SIGHUP'd itself, and so the child will always get SIGHUP if gio open's controlling tty is closed.

events.target_title: Support waiting for child process to exit in `gio open`

events.target_title: Evince should follow PageLayout PDF catalog key, at least its TwoPageRight value

note.body:
>How confusing. As a user, something that I have no idea about should decide how the pages of a document should be displayed, against all my preferences?

When you provide a two side document (e.g. created with the `book` class with LaTeX), you may want the reader to first have it displayed `TwoPageRight` in order he reads it "as a book". It is then up to reader to change the way the document is displayed, by using the features of its PDF viewer.

>If the user wants the document to be displayed like that, the user should enable the "Dual" option from the menu. Opening your test.pdf in Evince 3.30 and poppler 0.67, Evince shows page 1 on the right, and then page 2 and page 3 next to each other with page 2 on the left and page 3 on the right.

It is the same behavior in your installation but, precisely, I want the document to be automatically displayed with the "Dual" option (sorry, I wrote "Double" because it is the translation in French and I believed it was the same in English), even if this option wasn't enabled by user at the time he opened this document. In other words, the `TwoPageRight` value of `PageLayout` should IMO be taken in account by Evince.

events.target_title: Evince should follow PageLayout PDF catalog key, at least its TwoPageRight value

note.body:
>That sounds like a bad idea.

I fully disagree :)

> I can imagine enough "Why does Evince opens some PDFs in the Continuous mode which I've set, while my setting is ignored for other PDFs without any obvious pattern?" support questions.

Admittedly but this drawback could be avoided with a popup window warning the user, e.g. (the items of the list representing buttons):

  "The PDF you are opening asks to be open with some display options which are different from the Evince current ones. Do you accept it? 
* Yes, accept this time only.
* Yes, always accept (this may be changed in the preferences).
* No."

* No, never accept.

which would let you not be annoyed by this popup more than once.

events.target_title: Set keyring password earlier for Enterprise accounts

note.body:
GIS does show a password page for corp onboarding. When it asks for user and password, there's a way to get into "Enterprise Login Mode", where it shows (for example) an AD master (in the case of sssd-driven logins), a login field and a password field, then checks the user information entered in there against the server, and if the validation passes properly, allows the user to proceed to the next screen, which in my case is always the "Done!" page.

Relevant links:
* Button: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-initial-setup/blob/master/gnome-initial-setup/pages/account/gis-account-page.ui#L34-41
* Mode switch: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-initial-setup/blob/master/gnome-initial-setup/pages/account/gis-account-page.c#L87-114

events.target_title: fullscreen accelerated video freeze but audio continue with recent kernel

note.body:
Thanks for your interest Dan. I have a refresh rate of 60Hz and I use a 50" RCA TV via HDMI. In your bug repport I saw some persons reporting that Firefox is not concerned but it's probably false. If they set "layers.acceleration.force-enabled" in "about:config", the bug will probably happen. For me, the bug affect Chrome with hardware acceleration, Chromium with hardware acceleration, Chromium with GPU decoding and Firefox with hardware acceleration.

The bug is also not related to compositing in general. I tested XFCE with Compton since two week and I had absolutly no bug. 

Honestly I think at 99% that the bug concern only mutter with Xorg when a software use hardware acceleration. 

```
`[masou@debian-nuc ~]$ xrandr
Screen 0: minimum 320 x 200, current 1920 x 1080, maximum 8192 x 8192
DP-1 connected 1920x1080+0+0 (normal left inverted right x axis y axis) 983mm x 576mm
   1920x1080     60.00*+  50.00    59.94    30.00    25.00    24.00    29.97    23.98  
   1920x1080i    60.00    50.00    59.94  
   1600x900      60.00

   1280x720      60.00    50.00    59.94

DP-2 disconnected (normal left inverted right x axis y axis)
HDMI-1 disconnected (normal left inverted right x axis y axis)
`
```

events.target_title: fullscreen accelerated video freeze but audio continue with recent kernel

note.body:
It look like I found a solution. I Installed xserver-xorg-video-intel and I have also modified a little bit the Xorg configuration to avoid tearing on XFCE. Then for fun I tested it on Gnome-Shell and.... no more freeze! However I installed xserver-xorg-video-intel 1000 times during my test and it never changed anything exept now. So I will investigate a little bit more this week.

The only modification I made to Xorg is creating the file /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/20-intel.conf with this configuration:

```
Section "Device"
  Identifier  "Intel Graphics"
  Driver      "intel"
  Option      "TearFree" "true"
EndSection
```
**UPDATE:**
I can confirm that without "/etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/20-intel.conf", the bug happens. So the bug seem to be ralated to the kernel modesetting driver. Maybe the upgrade to xorg-server 1.20 also helped because I created many xorg.conf in the past 6 month and it's the first time something great happens! 

**UPDATE 2:**
I'm back with the modesetting driver because the xorg driver is too buggy for what i'm doing. So I just hope it will be fixed with gnome-shell 3.30!  

**UPDATE 3:** Still hapenning on gnome-shell 3.30 ...

events.target_title: The environment variable 'GIMP2_DIRECTORY' only works for the file 'gimprc'.

note.body:
Bonjour,

There is a small problem initially, if nothing exists :
You must add a file 'gimp.css' (even empty) and folders in the directory indicated by 'GIMP3_DIRECTORY'.

Here is the content of a .bat script that I used for testing :


```
IF NOT EXIST %CD%\Preferences (
mkdir %CD%\Preferences
)

IF NOT EXIST %CD%\Preferences\gimp.css (
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\backups
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\brushes
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\curves
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\dynamics
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\environ
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\filters
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\fonts
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\fractalexplorer
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\gfig
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\gflare
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\gimpressionist
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\gradients
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\icons
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\internal-data
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\interpreters
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\levels
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\modules
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\palettes
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\patterns
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\plug-ins
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\scripts
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\templates
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\themes
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\tmp
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\tool-options
mkdir %CD%\Preferences\tool-presets
echo /* You can add your own GIMP-specific GTK styles here */ > %CD%\Preferences\gimp.css
)

set GIMP3_DIRECTORY=%CD%\Preferences
start %CD%\bin\gimp-2.99.exe
exit
```

events.target_title: gnome-display-properties should pick the preferred xrandr mode

note.body:
Hi, I believe my issue is related.

Currently, Fn-F4 (or similar) can rotate through the dual monitor configurations (both, only primary, mirrored, only secondary). Once unplugged, it reverts back to primary-only.
It would be nice for RandR to remember where it stopped last time, and go back to that configuration (I want "only secondary", every time this monitor is plugged in).

Something like that has been suggested at https://wiki.gnome.org/Attic/RandR
It also mentions $(XDG_CONFIG_HOME)/monitors.xml, which remembers something (I have that file but do not seem to find my monitor there).

Perhaps a cookie for each monitor combination could be useful (e.g., a monitor configuration hash -> configured settings map).

If I have not done any error the generated code is exactly the same of before except for a (gchar*) cast added. So In my opinion this "patch" does not introduce any performance change and only remove some gcc "warning".

It is true that my solution is not a good solution only because I add a cast only to avoid warning but the warning was correct and the real issue is that the tmp variable has to be not cost.

The problem come from that for vala string is constant by default and there is no way to mark a string has mutable. A change for manage that is more complicated and change the language with possibility that something does not build any more.

So I think that my "solution" is acceptable.

events.target_title: Support PAN GlobalProtect VPN

note.body:
I'm unable to use NetworkManager based Global Protect VPN connections, while using 'openconnect' from command line works fine.

I can add the GP VPN connection type via GUI, and even get past the authentication (using a token).

According to log dump (from journalctl  -r -u NetworkManager.service), I see it:
"device (vpn0): Activation: successful, device activated." 

That's followed by reasonable looking "Data" entries presumably scrapped from the config HTTP response, but the end result is no default gateway is set.

Setup differences between working CLI and NM:
* CLI usage uses tun0 (vs vpn0) for interfaces, but guessing this doesn't matter.
* The working gateway is specified by 'default dev tun0 scope link', instead of route specific entry.
* "Server certificate verify failed: signer not found" error shows in NM usage.

I run Arch with following releases of OpenConnect and Networkmanager (and related plugins):
* networkmanager 1.20.6-1
* networkmanager-openconnect 1.2.6-1
* networkmanager-openvpn 1.8.10-1
* nm-connection-editor 1.8.24-1
* openconnect 1:8.05-1 (Note that version 8 introduced PA GPD support.)

Anything further I can do to debug this?

Update:
If I add the default gw manually below, it works via NM based connection.

route add default dev vpn0

events.target_title: [PATCH] Include preview thumbnail in internal link tooltips

note.body:
Unfortunately, I cannot try out Skim. I'd be interested to see what they do.

However, I've updated my patch to Mads's patch. Instead of hardcoding numbers, they are now dynamically calculated. Basically, the patch makes the preview as wide as possible, and tries to put the link slightly above the center of the preview. I'm pretty happy with it now. Only problem I currently see (but maybe not a big problem) is when zoomed in a lot, then equations in the left column and section headers on the right column are truncated. To solve that we would need to know more about the link, e.g. its size.

If anyone would like to try, I've put the patches on the `link_preview-3-30` branch in https://gitlab.gnome.org/hsgg/evince. Of course, I'd appreciate feedback.

events.target_title: Restore uncompressed xcf file from tmp if GIMP crashed during .xcf.* compression
Restore uncompressed xcf file from tmp if GIMP crashed during .xcf.* compression

note.body:
@Jehan oh, sorry. I wrongly assumed that the file was outdated. It took me a while to reconstruct what actually happened:

* Save large image as .xcfxz
* When the uncompressed file is saved in "tmp", GIMP allows editing during compression. This is a wonderful feature saving me a noticeable amount of time.
* Resize (upscale) the whole image with all its layers.
* Crash during resize operation

The resulting backup file is left in a corrupted state with a huge canvas and small unresized layers. I would have preferred to use the uncorrupted slightly older .xcf file from "tmp" instead. I believe that, in my specific situation, most users -- especially inexperienced users scared about the corrupted image -- would have preferred to do the same. However, contrary to me, they would not have even known about the existence of this file.

Happened using GIMP 2.10.4 (I see, I will update to 2.10.8 now) (64 bit) on Windows 10, 64 bit.

events.target_title: Crash with Fractal Trace filter

note.body:
The crash can be reproduced with the following command:  
```
$ gegl -- color crop width=100 height=100 fractal-trace fractal="julia" X1=-20.0 depth=4 abyss-policy="clamp"
```
The wrong pointer is initialized in [gegl_buffer_iterate_read_abyss_clamp](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gegl/blob/master/gegl/buffer/gegl-buffer-access.c#L1446) : read_buf = buf + (buf_offset_cols * bpp + buf_offset_rows * buf_stride);  

The calculated offset may be wrong : it happens when the roi passed to the function has a x (or/and y) value near the max limit of the integer type ; gegl_rectangle_intersect will fail to compute the intersection and return a null rectangle (0,0,0,0), producing bad values for buf_offset_cols and/or buf_offset_rows.  

This is the same kind of issue as in this report [gegl-sampler sometimes crashes for absurd coordinates](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gegl/issues/38)

Segfault on "from gi.repository import Gtk"

note.body:
Hi Christoph, sorry for being slow with response.

Since the time I reported it, I have switched nixpkgs (user/system packages) from unstable to stable. I have a bit older versions now:

```
glib-2.54.3-dev
gobject-introspection-1.54.1-dev
```

I don't get segfault now, but a different error:

```
$ python -c 'from gi.repository import Gtk' 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/alex/android/pygobject/gi/__init__.py", line 42, in <module>
    from . import _gi
ImportError: /nix/store/27x7pinqdsl9f3rpbm8bsszd9fhwq266-glibc-2.27/lib/librt.so.1: symbol __close_nocancel, version GLIBC_PRIVATE not defined in file libc.so.6 with link time reference
```

I get it in both cases:
- If I install pygobject from source in virtualenv
- If I use `python3.6-pygobject-3.26.1-dev` from nixpkgs
- (also it didn't work if I install pygobject from PyPI, but I didn't check it this time)

I haven't tried installing pygobject from source before.

From the error message, it looks like it may be a system issue, not related to Python or Gnome. But I'm not sure.

events.target_title: Support NFSv4

note.body: Yeah I'm already looking at it. I had both ideas but I am leaning towards folding it in with `nfs://` uris as it would match what the user expects to happen if they had used mount directly. It shouldnt be hard to do our own negotiation by trying nfsv4, if it fails try v3, if it still fails then its a real failure.

push_data.commit_title: nfs: Stat mount prefix before mounting

events.target_title: [WIP] NFS 4 Support
[WIP] NFS 4 Support

note.body:
This PR is still a work in progress, I am opening it to get early feedback from the GVFS maintainers. Current state is that protocol detection and mounting for file reads mostly work. Writes do not work at all.

Outstanding issues:
1. Writes fail, I believe this is a bug in the way libnfs reports errors for NFS v4 mounts, see [libnfs #265](https://github.com/sahlberg/libnfs/issues/265)
2. Occasionally, I see "invalid byte range" errors from the daemon and reads fail, there is no apparent pattern to this error that I can see
3. Occasionally, nautilus crashes while the new daemon is in use, again no apparent pattern. 

Plan is to get basic feature support (e.g. make writes work) and then drill into these issues.

These commits require an up-to-date version of libnfs. It remains to be seen if the build pipeline will need to be updated to use a more recent version.

note.body: I'll take a look at this, it's possible I can use those approaches instead but this looked very tied in to libnfs so I'm not sure. Really it would be kind of nice if libnfs exported the `wait_for_reply` function, and for that matter sync and async versions of the `nfs_version_detect` function
